SPOILER ALERT: The following piece contains plot details from â€œLa Chica o El Mundo,â€ the Season 1 finale of â€œPluribus,â€ now streaming on Apple TV.

The season finale of â€œPluribusâ€ opens with Kusimayu (Darinka Arones) surrounded by loved ones in their small Peruvian village. She is one of 13 survivors of the global shift known as The Joining, which has fused almost all of humanity into a single shared consciousness with whom sheâ€™s eager to merge. A special gas has been delivered via plane, and she happily inhales it, briefly convulsing in a state of hive-mind bliss. Sheâ€™s one of the Others now, and they all evacuate the village expeditiously. One down, 12 to go.

In the episode, titled â€œLa Chica o El Mundoâ€ (â€œThe Girl or the Worldâ€), a bloodied Manousos (Carlos Manuel Vesga) completes his death-defying journey from Paraguay to New Mexico. And Carol (Rhea Seehorn) is playing house with Zosia (Karolina Wydra). With the rest of the unaffected living in delusion and shooting the shit on weekly Zoom meetings, Manousos may be Carolâ€™s last hope at (in his view) saving humanity. But while heâ€™s been trekking through the DariÃ©n Gap and teaching himself English, Carolâ€™s been playing croquet and sleeping with the enemy.

Popular on Variety

The two â€œOld-Schoolers,â€ as the cast and crew of â€œPluribusâ€ refer to them, donâ€™t exactly get along. Manousos dumps Carolâ€™s phone through a drain grate, and they bicker about whether the Others are, in fact, people. Carolâ€™s situationship with Zosia has softened her views on the 7 billion people stricken with the mind virus, so much so that she threatens Manousos with a shotgun as he attempts to cure one of them with radio frequencies.

Eventually, Carol chooses the titular girl over the world, and she and Zosia embark on globe-trotting adventures, including a luxurious ski trip. The honeymoon phase comes to a screeching halt, however, when Zosia lets it slip that the Others have found a way to potentially convert Carol into one of them, against her will. It was previously established that they would need her stem cells, but their biological imperative prevents them from retrieving them via injection without her consent. Now, Zosia admits, the Others have discovered eggs that Carol had frozen with her late wife, Helen. Through a tricky, months-long process, they hope to convert the eggs into stem cells, which they could use to share their happiness with Carol.

This betrayal makes Carol go nuclear â€” literally. Remember when the Others told her theyâ€™d give her an atom bomb if she asked for one? Well, now they have. Back in Albuquerque, she and Manousos make a pact to save the world by any means necessary.

In two interviews, Seehorn and â€œPluribusâ€ creator Vince Gilligan, director-writer-EP Gordon Smith and writer-EP Alison Tatlock break down those finale twists and reveal their original, less explosive Season 1 ending.

A major revelation in this episode is that the Others have Carolâ€™s frozen eggs, which they can turn into stem cells, which they can use to convert her into one of them. Previously, they said they would need her consent â€” what changed?

GILLIGAN: Well, literally, the Others are very lawyerly. The specific question that was put to them â€” which they answered via signboard on that hotel casino in Las Vegas â€” was, â€œIs it true you need our stem cells?â€ And the answer was yes. Then Carol asked, â€œIs it further true that to collect those stem cells, you would need to stick a needle in my hip?â€ They were very cautious about how it was phrased. Itâ€™s like in Episode 2, when one of the characters says, â€œSo, you are vegetarians?â€ Thereâ€™s a little pause, and then Zosia says, â€œWe would prefer to be vegetarians, yes.â€ Itâ€™s very â€œPerry Masonâ€â€“esque, very lawyerly in how they answer questions. But nothing literally changed.

SMITH: We talked about the possibility that maybe they learned something new about Carolâ€™s eggs. They said at the very beginning, â€œWeâ€™re trying to figure out how to turn you.â€ And then they learned how to turn her. They can learn things.

TATLOCK: They donâ€™t need consent to change people, of course, because the premise of the show â€” right from the pilot â€” is that they change everybody as quickly as possible, first by kissing and eventually by planes flying overhead. If they could put their special spice in the water, they absolutely would. What they do need is consent to intrude upon somebodyâ€™s physical being. So they couldnâ€™t take her stem cells directly. But if her stem cells already exist â€” or if the eggs, which arenâ€™t stem cells, can be converted through a tricky process into stem cells â€” and theyâ€™re already outside of her body, theyâ€™ll do it.

So, itâ€™s still the case that they cannot lie, but they can withhold information?

GILLIGAN: They can mislead you all the live-long day. Absolutely. We were talking about â€œPerry Masonâ€ â€” the Raymond Burr version from the â€™50s. The famous moment in that show is when someone says, â€œWhat if I told you the killer was on the street at 3?â€ And later in the episode someone says, â€œYou told me the killer was on the street at 3,â€ and Raymond Burr says, â€œNo, I said, what if I told you.â€ Thatâ€™s the key to it. For us, with these folks, theyâ€™re very lawyerly.

SMITH: They can lie by omission.

Letâ€™s talk about Zosiaâ€™s betrayal of Carol.

SEEHORN: I donâ€™t think the betrayal could have been larger. Carol was living in a willing delusion. But there was always a part of her still in there. So, by the time Zosia says, â€œWe stole your eggs,â€ itâ€™s like: the eggs that represent the future that I wanted with my wife, who is now dead, partially because of you? And I also told you implicitly that I donâ€™t want this, and youâ€™re doing it behind my back? Itâ€™s also that horrible feeling of feeling like a fool for letting your guard down for a second. For Carol, itâ€™s magnified: How did I dare think I could have love and joy? On top of that, this massive clock is now ticking about how long Carol has before theyâ€™re going to turn her.

Courtesy of Apple

What is Zosiaâ€™s motive for kissing Carol in Episode 8?

TATLOCK: I think the motive behind the kiss, from the Othersâ€™ point of view, is to offer Carol something that would bring her comfort and pleasure and help her forget her troubles for a little while. I think itâ€™s an act of love in their mind. Now, watching it, you could say itâ€™s an act of manipulation, or maybe even worse. But from their point of view, they feel like theyâ€™re giving her something she longed for but wasnâ€™t able to fully take for herself, and that it would help her get through a hard, transitional chapter in her life â€” the chapter before being changed into one of them.

To what extent is Carol enamored by Zosia?

SEEHORN: Enamored is a great way to put it. I think she is sincerely enamored by her. The kiss is something Carol didnâ€™t even know how much she needed. Even when she runs down the driveway to hug her [in Episode 6], I think Carol is profoundly shaken and surprised by how much she â€” who used to be such a misanthrope and crave being alone all the time â€” could be pushed to the limits of realizing, I do need people. I need companionship. Voluntary isolation is a much different thing than involuntary isolation. Sheâ€™s in an extraordinarily vulnerable and fragile place in that scene.

As to whether the Others are â€œmanipulatingâ€ Carol, I suppose every action can be justified by, â€œWe just want to make you happy, Carol.â€ But at what point does making Carol happy mean the same thing as, â€œWeâ€™re going to give you everything you want so that we see eye to eye on things?â€ Itâ€™s not lost on me that Episode 8 is titled â€œCharm Offensiveâ€!

GILLIGAN: Youâ€™re definitely asking the right questions. What it boils down to is two people trying desperately to change each other. Itâ€™s a very dramatic set of circumstances, and I think about how this plays out in relationships all the time â€” people who love someone but also want to change them. You hear about that all the time: â€œWeâ€™re going to get married, and Iâ€™m going to change them.â€

SEEHORN: How do we separate altruism and manipulation? Most acts of kindness and love do have a payoff, even if itâ€™s just feeling good about yourself. Even unconditional love might be a child you have a responsibility to raise, or a fear of being alone, or a desire to receive love back. I honestly donâ€™t know the answer, and I havenâ€™t asked Vince to definitively tell me. I know heâ€™s thrilled that itâ€™s open to interpretation â€” whether the Others are being manipulative, whether theyâ€™re being sincere, and whether those two things can coexist.

Why does Carol threaten Manousos to stop experimenting on the Other? Sheâ€™s come a long way from how she felt at the beginning of the series.

SEEHORN: From the very beginning, as angry as Carol was â€” screaming at them, â€œYou murdered my wife, I want nothing to do with you!â€ â€” she always felt horrible about physically harming any of them. She always showed extreme guilt, even to the degree that she was willing to suppress her rage in order not to harm them. She even asks them at one point, when sheâ€™s in Spain, â€œCan you give me anything to make me stop doing this?â€ And thatâ€™s early on, when she still hates them.

Now, she has feelings for Zosia that are individualized, which illustrates to Carol that these are humans with a neurological shift, and they should not be harmed. So when she sees Manousos screaming at that guy shaking on the couch, she knows that not only could it cause Zosia to go into cardiac arrest, it could also mean killing millions of people all over the world again. And it infuriates her that he canâ€™t see any other way. At the same time, the audience knows sheâ€™s being extraordinarily defensive, because this guy can see through her. He knows sheâ€™s lying about why they came back and why she cares [about them] more now.

Courtesy of Apple

It seems like a lot of her conversation with Manousos is informed by the last couple days she spent with Zosia. Iâ€™m not sure she would have said the Others are â€œnot evilâ€ even a couple episodes ago.

SEEHORN: Fair point. The romantic part of it and feeling like she actually has a companion has muddied that. Some people have asked me if the Others leaving Carol in that extreme state of isolation was a manipulative tool to make her need them. I donâ€™t know the answer to that, and I hadnâ€™t even thought about it. I thought they were trying to protect themselves. But whatever the result is, Carol would absolutely see them coming back as an act of compassion. Many things have happened that make her feel like these people deserve compassion. They helped me. They put my Sprouts back. They made sure I was taken care of. Even when they couldnâ€™t stand me, they brought me anything I wanted. And when I needed companionship, they gave it to me.

We see the Other drive away, seemingly unfazed by Manousosâ€™ experiment. Just for the record: It did not work, correct? There is no way he has been converted back?

GILLIGAN: I never even thought of that.

SMITH: Heâ€™s not converted back. If he were converted back, Zosia would be doing something else. I donâ€™t think she would be walking out to leave Albuquerque. There would be a four-alarm fire on their hands.

TATLOCK: He would be very disoriented. He just looks placid and pleasant.

GILLIGAN: Rick! Thatâ€™s his name. Rick just gets in his Prius and leaves.

Surveillance is something Carol and Manousos bicker about. Manousos is more afraid than Carol about being spied on via digital devices. To what extent is that reasonable, or is he just paranoid?

TATLOCK: We know there are drones. Weâ€™ve seen the drones come in and out to deliver things. We know in the beginning Carol says, â€œAre you spying on me?â€ So, Manousos is not entirely wrong to suspect that theyâ€™re being watched. There are many reasons to believe someone is keeping an eye on them.

GILLIGAN: They basically have admitted that.

Why does Manousos start speaking to Zosia after months of staunchly resisting the Others? I mean, he decides to cross the DariÃ©n Gap so that he doesnâ€™t have to interact with them.

GILLIGAN: I think itâ€™s his interaction with Carol. Carol says to him, â€œHave you tried just talking to them?,â€ which is rich coming from her, because in Episode 2 the character Laxmi says to Carol, â€œHave you not asked these people questions? Why have you not asked them what itâ€™s like?â€ And now the shoe is on the other foot. Seven episodes later, Carol is saying, â€œWhy donâ€™t you just talk to these people?â€ And I think he takes her at her word. He tries it. And because he might be starting to feel like, I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m going to get straight answers from this woman whom I came 6,000 kilometers to talk to.

TATLOCK: Yeah, he becomes suspicious of Carol, so he decides to try a different tack, which is to get information about Carol from Zosia.

You have Chekhovâ€™s gun in this season. You also have Chekhovâ€™s atom bomb. When was it apparent that the nuke was going to be a major crux of this season?

GILLIGAN: Surprisingly late.

SMITH: A day or two into shooting the episode was when that became clear.

TATLOCK: It was not the ending we broke together in the writersâ€™ room. We adjusted it later, which is a bit unusual.

GILLIGAN: We had an ending that was perfectly good. It would have been satisfying but not as satisfying. And we got a note. You know the old thing about how executives always have stupid notes. Actually, Apple and Sony said, â€œIs there an even better ending to be had?â€ And we listened, and Iâ€™m really glad they gave us that note. It made for a better ending.

TATLOCK: We had planted the seed in Episode 3 but we didnâ€™t have an exact plan to pay it off in this way. It opened an opportunity to do that.

Can you share the ending you originally had planned?

SMITH: It was similar to that ending. It was more subtle. Carol secretly forges a pact with Manousos, slips him a note and is perhaps going to play double agent. There wasnâ€™t as much of a flag planted, like: â€œNope, Iâ€™m not doing this. This relationship with the Others canâ€™t continue.â€

GILLIGAN: Other than the atom bomb not being part of it, it was not open warfare. It was, Iâ€™m going to continue to be a double agent. It was covert. Even before we got the note, we thought, Is this the most satisfying way to go? Do we buy this?

Why do they give her the atom bomb? I know itâ€™s established early on, but if theyâ€™ll go against her wishes with the stem cells, why wonâ€™t they go against her wishes with the nuke?

GILLIGAN: Good question. They contain multitudes. Itâ€™s this constant tension between wanting to make her happy [and protecting themselves]. As horribly destructive as one atom bomb isâ€¦ obviously, they donâ€™t want her to set it off. But if she did â€” no pun intended â€” one atom bomb would not be the end of the world.

TATLOCK: There are 7 billion of them populating the entire Earth, so they are trying to placate her as best as they can, and they know they have the upper hand.

Courtesy of Apple

What would Earth look like if the Others converted everybody? In the opening scene of the finale, they immediately leave the village after converting Kusimayu, because they have no reason to be there. And those bodies have no reason to even be with each other anymore â€” that family has no purpose. In other words, who are the Others without the Old-Schoolers?

SMITH: In Episode 8, we hear about the dish theyâ€™re building, so we know they have some sense of purpose. Weâ€™re not 100% clear on what that looks like, or what the boundaries around that are, but we do think that it might be a nice world.

TATLOCK: Itâ€™s a peaceful world. Theyâ€™re a collective, and they are entirely pragmatic, so thereâ€™s no need anymore for them to recreate culture or to play pretend. If thereâ€™s no more Old-Schoolers left, they donâ€™t need to do what theyâ€™re doing for Mr. DiabatÃ© [Samba Schutte] or for Kusimayu. So, they are living as efficiently as possible and at peace with each other and with the Earth, but with no attachment.

GILLIGAN: The perfect reaction to the show is for the viewer to decide for themself: Is this paradise or is this hell? You could watch, for instance, the way the Others walk away from that Peruvian village and say, â€œOh my God, this is a nightmare. Suddenly everybody is cold to one another.â€ But if you look really closely, theyâ€™re not actually cold to each other. Theyâ€™re just there. Itâ€™s like all the cells in my body â€” Iâ€™m not paying attention to each one, but they make up one whole organism. They are happy, I think. But then again, is that paradise, or is it hell?

Why is it important that Carol is not necessarily always â€œlikableâ€ â€” or the perfect hero?

SEEHORN: She is a reluctant hero, to say the least. She definitely was not hoping to lead the revolution, but she feels like nobody else will. Her behavior is flawed because she is an everyman who is faced with an insane circumstance. She is not heightened. She is in a fantastical world, but she herself is utterly realistic, emotionally. What would you do if you found yourself feeling like you were in a dystopian, apocalyptic nightmare? Iâ€™d rather watch somebody misbehave in that moment, as long as itâ€™s truthful. Her vulnerability when she finds out that the other English speakers are all hanging out without her on weekly Zooms â€” thatâ€™s so human. Weâ€™ve all been there. I have been excluded from certain lunch tables in the cafeteria. That hurts, even when the big picture is much bigger.

I also find her suppression of rage very interesting to explore. I know sheâ€™s impulsive. I know she shouldnâ€™t be screaming or saying some of the things she says. But I also know that in my real life, many women I know should not be suppressing their anger and rage as much as they are. They should not be lowering their voices or trying so hard to be palatable. Those are flaws, too.

content:
Riding the phenomenal success of â€œDhurandhar,â€ which has emerged as one of the biggest Indian box office hits of 2025, the makers have locked the sequel for an Eid 2026 release.

The first installment follows a decade-long Indian intelligence operation where an undercover agent infiltrates Karachiâ€™s criminal and political underworld. The sequel is expected to continue from the cliffhanger ending.

Popular on Variety

Aditya Dhar directs the films, with Jio Studios and B62 Studios producing. Ranveer Singh leads the cast, with Akshaye Khanna playing the antagonist. The cast also includes Sanjay Dutt, R. Madhavan, Arjun Rampal, Sara Arjun, Rakesh Bedi, Manav Gohil, Danish Pandor, Saumya Tandon, Gaurav Gera and Naveen Kaushik.

content:
EXCLUSIVE: Love Island star Lana Jenkins has signed with emerging creator agency NAO Talent.

The TV personality and an industry make-up artist is known for her role in the winter season of ITV2â€™s Love Island Season 9 in the UK, where she ultimately ended up as a runner-up.

Since then, she has returned to make-up artist work on TV productions such as Channel 4 soap Hollyoaks, BBC drama The Responder and Sky comedy Brassic, and continued building her social media profile, with more than 700,000 followers across Instagram and TikTok.

Her content usually follows her sharing make-up videos, lifestyle updates and insights into life on set. She also launched an interview podcast, In the Makeup Chair, which features conversions with guests about beauty, business and behind-the-scenes life.

Watch on Deadline

Her new agency, NAO Talent, was quietly set up in September 2025 by creator-manager duo Amelia Olivia and Niamh Plunkett. They formed the business out of Oliviaâ€™s own creator career, after identifying a gap in the market for a management company that approaches careers and dealmaking from both a creator and commercial perspective.

Olivia is a well-established content creator who also began her career in the beauty industry. She has grown a community of more than 1.5 million subscribers across platforms.

â€œNAO Talent really was born out of our own lived experience,â€ Olivia told Deadline. â€œAs my career as a creator grew, my manager Niamh and I realised that creators are effectively building full-scale businesses, but most structures were still treating them like short-term marketing channels.

â€œWeâ€™d gone from small gifting deals to global partnerships and billboards and it became clear that what moved the needle wasnâ€™t luck, it was strategy, alignment and having someone in your corner who genuinely understands the creative and commercial sides of this industry. We launched NAO Talent together because there was a real gap for creator-first management that helps talent build sustainable, fulfilling careers â€“ not just chase the next campaign.â€

NAOâ€™s co-founders believe the creator economy has evolved to the point they need proper infrastructure and well-being support to handle their newly-found fame. â€œYoung creators are now founders, storytellers and cultural voices, but theyâ€™re often navigating brand deals, pricing, legal, creative direction and community management alone,â€ said Plunkett.

We hear NAO plans to unveil several new talent signings in early 2026.

â€œWeâ€™re interested in building careers,â€ added Olivia. â€œThat means thoughtful partnerships, long-term ambassadorships, creative collaborations and brand work that makes sense for the talent and their audience.

â€œWeâ€™re also intentional about helping creators build equity and IP â€“ whether thatâ€™s through product, media, licensing or other IP-driven opportunities. Thereâ€™s a huge shift happening where creators arenâ€™t just promoting brands, theyâ€™re co-creating them, and we want our talent to be at the forefront of that. Ultimately, we prioritise deals that feel aligned, strategic and sustainable â€“ where creators are seen as partners with perspective, not just content producers with reach.â€

Creator-focused agencies are popping in numbers as the industry evolves, with more and more stars who broken through on television shows signing with the newer companies or traditional agencies such as Curtis Brown, CAA or United Agents.

â€œAt the core of it, we just wanted to take everything weâ€™d learned â€“ the wins, the mistakes, the messy middle â€“ and use it to help other creatorsâ€™ build incredible careers that theyâ€™re proud of, from real, lived experience,â€ said Olivia.

content:
EXCLUSIVE: Fisayo Akinade and Kate Winslet hit it off the moment they met. After a coffee and a chat, she there and then offered him a role in Goodbye June, her directing debut that streams on Netflix from today following a limited theatrical run.

A few days prior to their meeting, Heartstopper actor Akinade, acclaimed for his virtuosity on stage, was on the top deck of a London bus when his agent called with the news The Holiday, The Reader and Mildred Pierce star was directing a film and wanted to meet. â€œI said, â€˜How the fuck does she know who I am?â€™â€

His agent then asked if heâ€™d like to know who he could be acting opposite. The names of Helen Mirren, Toni Collette, Timothy Spall, Johnny Flynn, Andrea Riseborough and Winslet herself were reeled off.

Watch on Deadline

â€œâ€˜What the fuck is going on?,â€™â€ he recalls spurting.

The film, written by Joe Anders, the son of Winslet and Sam Mendes, is about a matriarch of the family dying at Christmastime. Winslet wanted Akinade to play Angel, the cancer ward nurse caring for Mirrenâ€™s June, the title character, while her husband, their four children and grandchildren wait by her bedside.

The venue of the meeting was the Soho Hotel. As Akinade ran to the loo, Winslet came into view. â€œI thought, â€˜Jesus. This is a woman I have watched since I was about 12 years old, and sheâ€™s just here in the flesh â€“ so warm and lovely and funny and honest.â€™ We had coffee. She spoke about the film, spoke about herself, what sheâ€™d been up to, and then she said: â€˜Well, listen, I want you to do it. Thereâ€™s nobody else Iâ€™m seeing. Iâ€™m not asking anybody else.â€™â€

It was agreed and an offer was made. Winslet then suggested he accompany her on auditioning some children for the pic, and even reading with them. They left the hotel together and Akinade recalls finding the situation â€œinsane,â€ saying of Winslet, â€œShe has an air about her thatâ€™s just very easy and breezy â€“ I sort of liken it to how Denzel Washington and Pauletta Washington handle themselves. Theyâ€™re both very famous people, but then they just get about in a way that means people arenâ€™t flocking or hounding them.â€

Akinade took notice. â€œI do think itâ€™s something that you cultivate,â€ he says. â€œYou either choose to cultivate anonymity or you choose to cultivate fanfare.â€

Nigerian roots

Akinade was born in Liverpool, but when he was a baby he and his Nigerian parents went to Nigeria, returning to live in Manchester when he was an infant of four or five. By that time, the child could only speak Yoruba. â€œI knew loads of insults,â€ he says proudly.

His favourite phrase in Yoruba was to tell someone, â€œYouâ€™re the son of a goat and is your head all right?â€

Over breakfast at the Dean Street Restaurant in Soho, we chat about him playing nurse Angel, working with Winslet, with Judi Dench on The Vote and his analysis of the West End, and joke about what Nigerian traits we both might have. Weâ€™d been introduced a few weeks beforehand at a tea party for Winslet hosted by Netflix.

Iâ€™m not sure that I want to reveal it exactly, but we laughed over how we both show our displeasure. I will say that itâ€™s all very Nigerian!

Fisayo Akinade Baz

For the longest time Iâ€™d been aware of Akinadeâ€™s work on stage ever since he appeared as The Boy in a touring production of Samuel Beckettâ€™s Waiting for Godot. However, I really became aware of him when he appeared in the two dramas that Russell T Davies penned for Channel 4 in 2012, Banana and Cucumber.

He kept popping up all over the place and then Josie Rourke cast him in James Grahamâ€™s immersive 2015 general election drama The Vote at the Donmar Warehouse Theatre, where the theatrical all-star ensemble included Dame Judi, Mark Gatiss, Catherine Tate,Nina Sosanya, Timothy West, Rosalie Craig, Bill Paterson, Paul Chahidi, Jade Anouka, Jude Law, Finty Williams, Heather Craney, Hadley Fraser and Prasanna Puwanarajah.

I guess the point is: who wasnâ€™t in it?!

Like Dame Judi, Akinade enjoys doing crossword puzzles. â€œSheâ€™s the nicest woman alive,â€ he says, eyes sparkling as he recalls their time working on The Vote.

The immersive production had a handful of performances leading up to a live broadcast on election night, which I was lucky enough to attend, on More4. It was timed to end on the dot at 10pm local time when polls closed.

â€œInbuilt into the play were cues to let you know how far ahead or behind you were,â€ says Akinade. â€œThere was a point where we were a little bit behind hitting ten oâ€™clock, and someone came on and announced the time, which meant that we were behind. Judi out of nowhere started firing her lines out so quickly, and then everybody on stage started firing their lines too and we caught up in the play, ending bang on ten. Weâ€™d never hit that target before. It was amazing,â€ he marvels.

However, Akinade, in an astute analysis of the West End, feels that nowadays theater is â€œat a weird junctionâ€ because, he suggests, â€œThereâ€™s real pressure to make money and keep it robust. AI hurt and the writers and actors strikes in America hurt. Youâ€™ve got a lot of actors and and then thereâ€™s not enough money, so everyone who was doing prestige TV and film came down. The film stars started doing TV. The TV stars started doing plays, so it squeezed everybody down.â€

Look at the West End, for example, he argues: â€œThere is a celebrity in almost every show, and I get it because they need to pull [audiences], but whatâ€™s going to happen is people wonâ€™t go now unless thereâ€™s somebody recognizable in a lead role.

â€œBefore you could put a play like Downstate [Bruce Norrisâ€™s controversial drama about child-sex offenders] on at the National Theatre, and people would be like, â€˜Itâ€™s the greatest piece of fucking acting you will ever see from the greatest ensemble cast from [Steppenwolf] Chicago ever.â€™ It would sell out, whereas now, youâ€™ve got to put your stars in, otherwise youâ€™re screwed,â€ he says with concern in his voice.

To a point, because there are A-listers who are genuine creatures of the stage such as Billy Crudup and Denise Gough in High Noon at the Harold Pinter â€“ and what about Bryan Cranston, Marianne Jean-Baptiste and Paapa Essiedu in Ivo van Hoveâ€™s unbelievably powerful revival of Arthur Millerâ€™s All My Sons at Wyndhamâ€™s Theatre? Theyâ€™re all legit. â€œAnd thatâ€™s the nuance,â€ says Akinade. â€œHe [Crudup] happens to be very famous â€“ and heâ€™s a theater actor.â€

L/R Fisayo Akinade and Gemma Arterton in â€˜Saint Joanâ€™ Jack Sain

Not long after appearing in The Vote, the Donmar offered Akinade a role in George Bernard Shawâ€™s Saint Joan with Gemma Arterton, but the part in question wasnâ€™t for him. â€œVery early and quite riskily, I said no thank you to the Donmar,â€ he explains. The theater soon came back and asked him to play the Dauphin and he took it because he believes itâ€™s the best part in the play. â€œIt was one of the best times,â€ he recalls. â€œI just got to be a petulant king and it was so fun.â€

Turning down the initial part was â€œscaryâ€ because, â€œIf youâ€™re not working as an actor, you are not earning a thing,â€ he says. â€œYou may have to do a few shifts in the pub, but now having been 14 years in [the business], the power of â€˜noâ€™ is so important. You really have to, for yourself, determine what you are going to do and what you will not do. What you say â€˜noâ€™ to is far more important than what you say â€˜yesâ€™ to.â€

What will he not do? â€œAll I want to do is play roles that have interesting arcs â€“ a character is different at the end of the thing than they are at the beginning,â€ he says. â€œTheyâ€™re changed somehow. I donâ€™t care about being the lead or supporting character.â€

For example, the Reverend Hale part,which the actor played in Arthur Millerâ€™s The Crucible directed by Lyndsey Turner at the National Theatre, is for him the greatest arc in that play because the character is â€œsomebody that is so devout and utterly convicted â€“ and then he sees that this divine thing he has spent his life devoted to is corruptible. I just find that shift so potent,â€ he reasons.

L-R: Erin Doherty and Fisayo Akinade in â€˜The Crucibleâ€™ Johan Persson

Itâ€™s the same reason he played Mercutio in Romeo and Juliet opposite Josh Oâ€™Connor and Jessie Buckley in director Simon Godwinâ€™s production that was bound for the National Theatre until Covid happened and it was filmed for the National and Sky Arts.

National Theatre at home.

Background work

Akinade says that Winslet set up hands-on-experience meetings with two palliative care nurses on a cancer ward at a London hospital in preparation for his role. What was important for Akinade is that Muti Akinade, his mom, has been a carer for most of his life â€“ first with the elderly and now with people with adult learning difficulties.

He felt the role allowed him to pay homage to his mother. â€œThe way my mum cares is very Nigerian, so it is very tough love, monumental love. She had all these amazing techniques for getting in and soothing, so thatâ€™s one aspect that I wanted to bring to Angel.â€

One of the nurses Winslet introduced him to was a 30-year veteran who still had the enthusiasm for care, compassion and empathy â€œdespite the hours, despite the pay, despite how theyâ€™re sometimes treated, despite all of the things NHS nurses have to endure.â€

The nurse alos provided the actor with one of the filmâ€™s best lines. â€œShe said, â€˜When a patient comes in for end of life care, my first thought is that we have to get it right. We have to make sure this person gets a good goodbye.â€™â€

L-R: Johnny Flynn as Connor, Andrea Riseborough as Molly, Timothy Spall as Bernie, Kate Winslet as Julia and Fisayo Akinade as Angel in â€˜Goodbye Juneâ€™ Kimberley French/Netflix

Akinade texted Winslet referencing the â€œgood goodbyeâ€ adage and her immediate response was, â€œâ€˜Thatâ€™s going in the film.â€™ And then it did.â€ Sipping his coffee, he adds: â€œThat was just so beautiful because thatâ€™s a real life quote from a real NHS nurse, and it was just very important to me to represent the NHS properly.â€

As the film plays out, Angel observes the four siblings, especially the petty quarrels between the sisters played by Winslet and Riseborough. Wisely, he well understands that families bicker but knows the arguments should come later. â€œWhen your mum goes, are you going to be thinking about what happens to her ring, or are you just going to be missing your mum,â€ asks Akinade of his characterâ€™s motivations. â€œYou can fight later. None of this is important.â€

I realize that I had watched the film through Angelâ€™s eyes. Itâ€™s his common sense that helps get the family in shape to see whatâ€™s happening to the matriarch. Iâ€™m a fervent believer in gaining wisdom from art.

Akinade agrees and says that Steven Spielbergâ€™s film The Color Purple â€œwas one of the most formativeâ€ heâ€™s seen because â€œthereâ€™s a woman that is horrendously abused who not only finds her power, but also finds love in that.â€

He watched the film with his mother at a time when he was being bullied at school. â€œAnd she knew that,â€ he recalls. â€œSo she was like, â€˜Come and watch this.â€™ She was essentially saying, â€˜Look what happened to this woman. Look. And now look at her at the end. Look how happy she is. Look how free sheâ€™s about to be. Youâ€™ll be all right.â€™â€

Sunday was their day to sit and watch films. It could be The Golden Voyage of Sinbad and The Clash of the Titans. One day when he was maybe 13, he watched Philadelphia, starring Tom Hanks and Denzel Washington. â€œIt was probably too soon, but that was deeply, profoundly moving for me and I donâ€™t think my mum or dad at the time understood why,â€ says Akinade. â€œFor me, I was like, â€˜Oh, look at this man defending this gay manâ€¦ with such conviction.â€™â€

It was very surreal moment, he says, when he appeared in Jeremy O. Harrisâ€™s Slave Play featuring Olivia Washington when he got to meet her parents, Pauletta Washington and Denzel Washington. â€œHe was just ginormous in his energy, but so warm,â€ says Akinade. â€œHe turned to me and exclaimed, â€™Oh, you. Youâ€™re really good.â€™ He pulled me into a bear hug and then sort of jokingly said, â€˜If you keep going, you can be something special.â€™ That is all I will need for the rest of my days,â€ he says with a satisfied sigh.

All of this was happening around the time Denzelâ€™s son, Malcom Washington, was preparing his film, The Piano Lesson, for that yearâ€™s awards season. Suddenly, he and I are heaping praise on Danielle Deadwyler with Akinade insisting that â€œsomebody give her the Viola [Davis] treatmentâ€ and find her roles that catapult her star. We spend an inordinate about of time discussing the roles both Deadwyler and Davis have played on screen.

L-R Helen Mirren as June and Kate Winslet as Julia in â€˜Goodbye Juneâ€™ Kimberley French/Netflix

Akinade recalls being in a cinema and â€œliterally levitatingâ€œ when he watched Davis standing toe-to-toe with Meryl Streep in Doubt.

During a conversation last summer, Winslet revealed to me that Akinadeâ€™s role as Angel originally wasnâ€™t as big a part as it has now become. â€œHeâ€™s so bloody good, he can do anything,â€ she said. The part grew through the two of them â€œjust chatting,â€ is how Akinade puts it.

â€œI would get a text every now and then saying, â€˜We just added thisâ€™ or â€˜I think weâ€™re going to get you more involved in this bit.â€™ I thought thatâ€™s really lovely because as much as it is a film about a familyâ€™s matriarch dying and the family coming back together, I also think itâ€™s a real love letter to carers, nurses and the NHS, and the ways in which those people in that institution take care of the entire [British] nation for free.â€

He becomes visibly moved as he explains that his own father had been treated for cancer. â€œHe beat cancer twice because of care â€“ and he had that care for free.â€

Akinade reckons that because Winslet gave him so much more to do in the film, â€œThat through line became more potent â€“ and therefore more personal for me â€“ because itâ€™s just a lovely little side story.â€

Avoiding tokenism

I love that Angel is not a black character that can be deemed token. Akinade laughs then observes sharply that this canâ€™t be the case when it comes to the NHS, â€œBecause you go to any hospital and whoâ€™s looking after you?â€ He adds: â€œYes, it would have been tokenism if it wasnâ€™t true.â€

His mother was very touched by Angel when she attended the London premiere. What the character does for the family in Goodbye June is such an act of empathy and generosity, the kind thatâ€™s not often publicly highlighted. Akinadeâ€™s a big brother to two sisters. His parents live in Manchester, as does his younger sibling, while his middle sister resides in London. He loves going home to visit where â€œitâ€™s the place Iâ€™m my most comfortable self anywhere.â€

There was never any pressure from his parents about him becoming an actor. They knew that the life is not always the easiest, but heâ€™s grateful that they never suggested he become a doctor. Once they saw he was getting theater work regularly and then cast in Banana and Cucumber they knew he would be alright.

His widest variety of roles have been on stage. â€œThereâ€™s a bit more imagination there,â€ he says. However, he has had the best time working on screen in all manner of shows, including Heartstopper. In the Netflix series he plays Mr. Ajayi, and lauds the series for doing â€œso much for young LGBTQ people.â€

Some people watching it, he says, â€œWish theyâ€™d had this level of freedom, openness and care when I was at school because it does feel, in some cases, easier to be open and out about your sexuality or gender identity or whatever it may be now, than it was then, which is amazing.â€

Fisayo Akinade in â€˜Heartstopperâ€™ Netflix

Working on other shows has been helpful for him, he says. â€œIâ€™ve been gay a very long time, but when Cucumber was coming out I was like, â€˜How do I navigate this?â€™ I called Russell T. Davis and he met me in Pret in Euston Station, and said, â€˜Thereâ€™s one question and one answer. Are you gay? Yes you are.â€™ He said, â€˜If you donâ€™t [embrace] that, you will spend your life terrified of being caught out and found outâ€¦You will be a half version of yourself. So are you? Yes. And on you move.â€™

â€œThen you are unburdenedâ€¦ from the fear of being caught out. It was a scary thing [but] it actually hasnâ€™t held me back.â€

Quite right too. Why should it matter? There are too many meaningless distinctions, he argues, but there are some useful ones too, he suggests. For instance, â€œYou want to buy a sofa. When you talk to the assistant, you say, â€˜I would like a soft sofa or a big sofa or an L-shaped sofa. Theyâ€™re useful distinctions for what you want.

â€œBut when you say to a person, â€˜Daniel Day Lewis, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Meryl Streep, Julia Roberts, they are actors. Chiwetel Ejiofor, Forest Whittaker, Viola Davis, Taraji P. Henson, theyâ€™re black actors. Why? Whatâ€™s the difference? The job is exactly the same. So why put in the word black or gay or northern or working class before the job of actor, what does it do? What function does that distinction have? Serves no purpose or other than to other.â€

Continuing, he says: â€œThere are people that act and there are black people that act. I think that sets off prejudices in peopleâ€™s heads.â€

But sometimes the casting of an actor who is black can transform a role. We both jump on Cynthia Erivo in Wicked as an example. â€œHaving a black woman play that role makes Elphabaâ€™s difference more potent,â€ he says. â€œAs soon as you include a person of color in something, it is going to be whether consciously or unconsciously, an aspect of that is going to become racialized â€“ of course it is. Now you have Elphaba whoâ€™s green, played by a black woman. There is another layer, another nuance, that is challenging audiences to invest on a deeper level.â€

Upcoming he has a television drama which for now heâ€™s not able to discuss. In any event, he says heâ€™s lucky to have worked with great stars such as Mirren and Dench. Initially, he admits he was â€œscaredâ€™â€ of meeting the former â€œbecause sheâ€™s Helen Mirren,â€ but he didnâ€™t need to worry. â€œShe was just the loveliest, so not starry and down to earth.â€

The same was true for Dame Judi. When they did a run-through of The Vote at a church hall in Islington, he arrived early, and Dench and Finty Williams, her daughter, pitched up shortly afterwards. â€œShe went, â€™Hello, Iâ€™m Judiâ€™â€¦ And she went, â€˜Feel my palm. Feel itâ€¦ thatâ€™s cold sweat. Iâ€™m fucking terrified. Donâ€™t judge me on what I do today.â€™ I said, â€˜But youâ€™re fucking Judi Dench!â€™ She said, â€˜I fucking know who I am. Donâ€™t judge me.â€™ And I was like, â€˜Well, I wonâ€™t. Of course not.â€™â€

Fisayo Akinade is already a great actor and a deeply caring dude. Thatâ€™s why he steals Goodbye June with one tiny line.

title: A Look Ahead At Londonâ€™s West End In 2026: Cynthia Erivo, Josh Oâ€™Connor, Tilda Swinton & Gary Oldman Among Stars Returning To The Theater
summary: More and more screen stars will return to their theatrical roots in 2026 to give their stage muscles a workout. Wickedâ€™s Cynthia Erivo is back after a 12-year absence to the West End, as Deadline was first to report, to play all 23 roles in a bloodthirsty version ofÂ Dracula. content:
More and more screen stars will return to their theatrical roots in 2026 to give their stage muscles a workout. Wickedâ€™s Cynthia Erivo is back after a 12-year absence to the West End, as Deadline was first to report, to play all 23 roles in a bloodthirsty version of Dracula. Josh Oâ€™Connor, a lead in next yearâ€™s Steven Spielberg blockbuster Disclosure Day, will trace the downfall of a classical violinist who opts instead for a bruising life as a boxer in a rare revival of Clifford Odetsâ€™ Golden Boy.

So why do they do it? Theyâ€™re both screen idols in demand and their agents have endless goodies lined up for them, yet theyâ€™d rather face the harsh glare of a follow spot.

Watch on Deadline

Erivo & Oâ€™Connor

Josh Oâ€™Connor Theo Wargo/Getty Images

Both Erivo and Oâ€™Connor are legitimate creatures of the stage and both tell me they miss it. They also say that it terrifies them. â€œItâ€™s like running towards the fire,â€ Erivo says. â€œIâ€™m doing Dracula because it scares the sh*t out of me,â€ they add.

Oâ€™Connor says he wants to re-experience the danger of performing in front of a live audience where thereâ€™s â€œno safety net.â€

During a chat with him as he wraps on Spielbergâ€™s picture, he chose the word that sums it all up: â€œItâ€™s the fear. Actors love it.â€

Erivo is now in London sinking her teeth into rehearsals with director Kip Williams for the 112 performances they will give at the Noel Coward Theatre over a 15-week season beginning February 4. Should they need to take a flight to attend awards shows across the pond, some dates have been blocked off.

Cynthia Erivo at the â€œWicked: For Goodâ€ New York premiere Getty Images

The Tony winner and Oscar nominee was last on stage in the West End when they appeared with Harriet Walter in Phyllida Lloydâ€™s production of Henry IV, set in a prison, at the Donmar Warehouse in 2014. From there, Erivo headed to Broadway to play Celie in The Color Purple. They tell us that theyâ€™re using their own talon-like fingernails to play Bram Stokerâ€™s vampire.

Their astonishing performance as Elphaba in Jon M. Chuâ€™s two Wicked moves proves they have the stamina to command the stage of the Noel Coward, performing multiple roles. Erivo says they were convinced they could do it after seeing Sarah Snook play 26 different characters in The Picture of Dorian Gray on Broadway.

Both Dracula and Dorian Gray originated out of the Sydney Theatre Company and were directed by Williams. Producers Michael Cassel and Adam Kenwright are responsible for bringing them to London. Snook took The Picture of Dorian Gray to Broadway, and although no oneâ€™s saying so out loud, Dracula is likely going to rest in their sarcophagus and be transported to New York as well.

Sam Yates, who directed Andrew Scott in Vanya at the Old Vic and in New York, will begin rehearsals with Oâ€™Connor and the Golden Boy company as soon as The Crown, Challengers and Godâ€™s Own Country star completes red carpet duties for Disclosure Day, which opens June 12.

Oâ€™Connor, currently seen in Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery, The Mastermind and The History of Sound, also needs to get into prizefighting shape for Golden Boy, which runs at the Almeida from September 8-October 31.

Swinton & Oldman

Tilda Swinton Courtesy Royal Court

Elsewhere, Oscar-winning actors Tilda Swinton and Gary Oldman are both returning to their theatrical roots at the same address, the Royal Court in Sloane Square, to help celebrate its 70th anniversary.

The last time Swinton trod the boards was in Manfred Kargerâ€™s Man to Man for the playâ€™s 1988 London premiere. It had transferred down from Edinburghâ€™s Traverse Theatre where it originated in 1987 with Swinton taking up the solo role of Ella Gericke, a German widow who, beginning in the 1930s, assumes the identity and work of Max, her deceased husband, to help her through years of tumultuous upheaval in her country. I saw her do it at the Royal Court and she was pretty remarkable; thrilling that Swinton has signed up to take the part on again with Man to Manâ€˜s original creative team led by director Stephen Unwin.

Iâ€™m curious to see if Swintonâ€™s reemergence on stage encourages her to perform more in the theater. Donâ€™t want to boast, but Iâ€™m going to anyway â€” I saw her perform a variety of roles opposite the likes of Judi Dench and Peggy Mount in the Royal Shakespeare Companyâ€™s legendary 1982-85 seasons at Stratford-upon-Avon and the Barbican, in Mother Courage and Her Children (with Dench and ZoÃ« Wanamaker) and Measure for Measure (with Mount, Daniel Massey and Juliet Stevenson playing Isabella). Swinton had small and large roles in other plays that performed in the repertory.

The very last time Swinton took a bow was in Unwinâ€™s production of Peter Handkeâ€™s The Long Way Round at the National Theatre 35 years ago. Having seen it, I can understand why she stayed away so long!

Man to Man plays the Royal Courtâ€™s Jerwood Theatre Downstairs begins September 5. It will transfer to New York in spring 2027.

Gary Oldman Dan Doperalski/GG2025/Penske Media via Getty Images

Slow Horses star Oldman precedes Swinton into the Jerwood Downstairs with Samuel Beckettâ€™s Krappâ€™s Last Tape, which originated at the Royal Court in 1958. Oldman recently revived the one-man drama, in which he both starred in and directed, at York Theatre Royal last April and May.

Oldman performed in a series of plays at the Royal Court over a two-year period beginning in 1985, culminating in a breathtaking performance opposite Lesley Manville in Serious Money, Caryl Churchillâ€™s ferocious takedown of high finance.

Krappâ€™s Last Tape runs from May 8.

Chris Pine

Chris Pine and â€˜Ivanovâ€™ The Bridge Theatre

Chris Pine (Star Trek, Into the Woods) makes his London stage debut as Anton Chekhovâ€™s angst-ridden Nikolai Ivanov in a new adaptation of Ivanov by Simon Stone running at the Bridge Theatre from July 4-September 19.

Some folk I know rolled their eyes when they heard about Pineâ€™s casting to play a man undone by his own malaise. But Pineâ€™s a classically trained thespian who studied at UC Berkeley and Leeds University before undertaking further acting courses at ACT in San Francisco. I feel we shouldnâ€™t disdain American screen actors who come here to tread our boards with serious intent. Although itâ€™s true that some, more homegrown than Americans, do venture from screen to stage and itâ€™s clear they havenâ€™t the chops for it, still they rake in the money at the box office in any old slop, and audiences leave disappointed because the star from the telly was a dud. Tisâ€™ not the season to name names.

Ivanovâ€™s tricky to pull off so kudos to Pine for running towards the fire. By the way, my benchmark for Ivanov, gawd knows Iâ€™ve seen a few, is Ralph Fiennes who was luminous in a crackerjack production that Jonathan Kent directed at the Almeida in 1997 from a version by David Hare.

Ivanov plays the Bridge Theatre from July 4-September 19.

Rosamund Pike in â€˜Inter Aliaâ€™ Mads Perch

Tom Stoppard had already approved the casting for the Old Vicâ€™s revival of his 1993 masterpiece Arcadia before he died late last month. Carrie Cracknellâ€™s now in rehearsals with a company that includes Isis Hainsworth, Seamus Dillane, Prasanna Puwanarajah, Leila Fazad, Fiona Button, Holly Godliman, Angus Cooper, Gabriel Akuwudike and William Lawlor. The story is that of a child prodigy and theories of literary scandal and scientific intrigue that moves between two eras.

Felicity Kendal, Bill Nighy, Harriet Walter, Samuel West and Emma Fielding were in the original company at the National that Trevor Nunn directed. What an opening night that was!

Kendal, a Stoppard muse, can be seen currently in the playwrightâ€™s 1995 play Indian Ink directed by Jonathan Kent at Hampstead Theatre until January 31.

Meanwhile, Rosamund Pike (Gone Girl, The Wheel of Time) reprises her star turn in the transfer of Suzie Millerâ€™s searing legal drama Inter Alia from the National, where it was a sold-out hit, to Wyndhamâ€™s Theatre from March 19-June 20.

Pike is joined by Jamie Glover, who played her husband in the NT production directed by Justin Martin. Itâ€™s about a karaoke-loving Old Bailey judge who finds herself at the center of an ethical conundrum involving her college-age son.

Millerâ€™s other legal scorcher, Prima Facie, is going on tour. The one-woman drama, a soaraway success in London and on Broadway, saw Jodie Comer win Tony, Olivier, Evening Standard and all the silverware going for her portrait of an attorney who represents alleged sexual offenders and is herself raped. Play opens at Richmond Theatre, south west of London, on January 23 and then plays eight other dates from Dublinâ€™s Gaiety Theatre to the Playhouse in Liverpool, wrapping there March 21.

Clint Dyer (Get Up, Stand Up!, Death of England Plays), the former National Theatre deputy artistic director and now an NT Artistic Associate, directs Aaron Pierre (The Morning Show, Lanterns, Rebel Ridge, The Underground Railroad) playing Randle P. McMurphy in the stage production of Ken Keseyâ€™s One Flew Over the Cuckooâ€™s Nest adapted by Dale Wasserman.

Aaron Pierre Peyton Fulford

Olivier Award-winner Giles Terera (Hamilton, Rosmersholm, Othello), a frequent collaborator of Dyerâ€™s, plays Dale Harding, the savviest patient in the psychiatric facility who initially locks horns with McMurphy. The play runs at the Old Vic from April 1-May 23. William Redfield (A New Leaf, Death Wish) played Harding in Milos Formanâ€™s classic 1975 movie, and we all know Jack Nicholson took on McMurphy.

Iâ€™m hearing of some cool casting ideas in the works for Nurse Ratched, who was played by Louise Fletcher in the film.

Dyer also directs Letitia Wright (Black Panther, Small Axe) in the UK premiere of Tracey Scott Wilsonâ€™s incendiary drama The Story, about a reporter who clashes with their editor (whatâ€™s new!) over a hot-button issue. Throw in some racism and journalistic ethics into the mix.

Letitia Wright Jeff Spicer/Getty for Warner Bros. Pictures

Marianne Elliott directs a major-league revival of Christopher Hamptonâ€™s Les Liasons Dangereuses from Pierre Choderlos de Laclosâ€™ epistolary novel starring Lesley Manville, Monica Barbaro and Aidan Turner at the National from March 21-June 6.

Also National Theatre bound is the musical adaptation of the 2014 movie Pride written by Stephen Beresford and directed by Matthew Warchus. They reunite for this new show, which has been developed by Warchus with Beresford writing the book and lyrics, with music by Christopher Nightingale, Josh Cohen and DJ Walde.

Lesley Manville and Aidan Turner in artwork for â€˜Les Liasons Dangereusesâ€™ National Theatre

Pride is inspired by the true tale of how a group known as â€œLesbians and Gays Support the Minersâ€ came to the aid of a Welsh pit village during the 1984 minerâ€™s strike. The movie starred Ben Schnetzer, Andrew Scott, Imelda Staunton, Paddy Considine, Jessica Gunning, George MacKay, Dominic West, Monica Dolan and Liz White.

The musical plays the Nationalâ€™s Dorfman Theatre from June 11-September 12.

However, the keenest amongst you should scoot off to Cardiffâ€™s Sherman Theatre for Prideâ€™s outta town world premiere from March 31 through April 18.

Happy Valleyâ€™s Siobhan Finneran stars in J.B. Priestleyâ€™s great farce When We Are Married, which is on now at the Donmar Warehouse, directed by Tim Sheader, until February 7. Finneganâ€™s joined by Samantha Spiro, Sophie Thompson, Tori Allen-Martin, Leo Wringer and Ron Cook.

(L-R) Sophie Thompson, Siobhan Finneran and Samantha Spiro in â€˜When We Are Marriedâ€™ Johan Persson

The best ever production of When We Are Married starred Patricia Routledge, Timothy West, Prunella Scales, Brian Murphy, Bill Fraser, Patsy Rowlands and Patricia Hayes at the old Whitehall Theatre (now the Trafalgar) in 1985. Watching them was pure comedy gold.

Following Finneran and company into the Donmar from February 14 is Anastasia Hille (The Bletchley Circle, A Gentleman in Moscow) and Erin Kellyman (28 Years Later, The Falcon and the Winter Soldier) in the world premiere of Evening All Afternoon by Anna Ziegler (Photograph 51), about how a stepmother and her stepdaughter summon quiet courage â€œto open their hearts again.â€

Chiwetel Ejiofor has been spotted at rehearsals in Clapham, South London for the Royal Shakespeare Companyâ€™s musical adaptation of The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind, based on Ejioforâ€™s 2019 Netflix movie about how schoolboy William Kamkwamba, then aged 13, saved his village in Malawi from famine by devising a windmill from scratch to provide electricity to pump water and irrigate crops.

Ejiofor has been appointed the showâ€™s creative associate and is on hand should director Lynette Linton, the cast and creatives require any guidance related to the story. Kenny Wax, who holds the West End rights, tells me that the cast, with Alistair Nwachukwu as William, have been â€œraising the roofâ€ over at the RSCâ€™s London rehearsal hall. The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind opens at the RSCâ€™s Swan Theatre in Stratford-upon-Avon on February 10 and runs through March 28. The show features book and lyrics by Richy Hughes and music and lyrics by Tim Sutton.

It then transfers to @sohoplace in the West End from April 25-July 18.

Alistair Nwachukwu Dujonna

Nwachukwu was a member of the ensemble that performed in the excellent play The Line of Beauty, based on Alan Hollinghurstâ€™s bestselling novel. It was directed by Michael Grandage and adapted by Jack Holden, who described it as a drama â€œabout class and furniture.â€ Anyhow, thereâ€™s no word yet on when, where and casting, but itâ€™s likely to transfer into the West End. Jasper Talbot, Leo Surer, Ellie Bamber, Arty Froushan, Charles Edwards, Claudia Harrison, Robert Portal and Francesca Amewudah-Rivers were at the top of their game when I caught the final Almeida performance.

The aforementioned Froushan will headline, as we reported here recently, a revised revival of the musical version of Bret Easton Ellisâ€™ notorious novel American Psycho directed again by Rupert Goold. Show features a book by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa and music and lyrics by Duncan Sheik. It runs at the Almeida from January 22-March 14.

More from the RSC: Kenneth Branagh returns to Stratfordâ€™s Royal Shakespeare Theatre to play Prospero in The Tempest, directed by Richard Eyre, with performances from May 13 through June 20.

Branagh also appears with Academy Award-winning Helen Hunt making her RSC debut as Ranyevskaya in Chekhovâ€™s The Cherry Orchard directed by Tamara Harvey from a new version by Laura Wade. A limited season at The Swan Theatre runs July 10-August 29.

Helen Hunt

Mark Gatiss also debuts at the RSC in Bertolt Brechtâ€™s The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui, in a version by Stephen Sharkey thatâ€™s directed by SeÃ¡n Linnen, also at The Swan, from April 11 through May 30.

High Noon, adapted from the classic Western by Eric Roth, is in previews at the Harold Pinter Theatre with Billy Crudup and Denise Gough playing, and expanding, the roles played by Gary Cooper and Grace Kelly in Fred Zinnemannâ€™s movie written by Carl Forman. Roth tells me itâ€™s about â€œcourage.â€

Arthur Millerâ€™s All My Sons is unmissable at Wyndhamâ€™s Theatre starring Bryan Cranston, Marianne Jean-Baptiste, Paapa Essiedu, Tom Glynn-Carney and Hayley Squires. The magnificent production directed by Ivo van Hove opened to rave notices a few weeks back, but it runs until March 7.

And we delivered you the scoop on Sadie Sink (Stranger Things) and Noah Jupe (Hamnet) making their West End debuts in Romeo & Juliet directed by Robert Icke, which runs at the Harold Pinter Theatre beginning March 16 for a limited season until June 6. The full company rehearse late January.

Sadie Sink and Noah Jupe Helen Murray

A tip: Theo Jamieson, musical director at the Royal Shakespeare Company, has written the book, music and lyrics for a new musical developed at the National Theatre Studio called Flyby. Thereâ€™s talk of it heading to Southwark Theatre at some point next year starring Poppy Gilbert (Sherwood, Chloe). From what Iâ€™m hearing, Gilbert is a revelation.

You heard it here first.

title: Donald Trump Rages Over â€˜Pathetic Trainwreckâ€™ Stephen Colbert, Says CBS Should Cancel His Show Now: â€˜Put Him to Sleepâ€™
summary: On Tuesday night, after CBS aired the Kennedy Center Honors ceremony — hosted by President Donald Trump — Trump was focused not on his historic turn as emcee of the event, which took place earlier this month at what he and his allies have renamed the Trump Kennedy Center (a move experts say is illegal). […]
content:
On Tuesday night, after CBS aired the Kennedy Center Honors ceremony â€” hosted by President Donald Trump â€” Trump was focused not on his historic turn as emcee of the event, which took place earlier this month at what he and his allies have renamed the Trump Kennedy Center (a move experts say is illegal).

Instead, Trump was fuming about Stephen Colbert, the CBS late-night show host who, in the final season of â€œThe Late Showâ€ on the network, continues to relentlessly ridicule the president. Trump urged CBS to pull the plug on Colbertâ€™s show â€œNOWâ€ instead of ending its run next May.

Popular on Variety

â€œStephen Colbert is a pathetic trainwreck, with no talent or anything else necessary for show business success,â€ Trump wrote in a post at 12:16 a.m. ET on his Truth Social platform. â€œNow, after being terminated by CBS, but left out to dry, he has actually gotten worse, along with his nonexistent ratings. Stephen is running on hatred and fumes ~ A dead man walking! CBS should, â€˜put him to sleep,â€™ NOW, it is the humanitarian thing to do!â€

Seven minutes later, Trump followed up with this: â€œWho has the worst Late Night host, CBS, ABC, or NBC??? They all have three things in common: High Salaries, No Talent, REALLY LOW RATINGS!â€

Trump also reiterated his call for the U.S. government to revoke TV broadcastersâ€™ licenses. â€œIf Network NEWSCASTS, and their Late Night Shows, are almost 100% Negative to President Donald J. Trump, MAGA, and the Republican Party, shouldnâ€™t their very valuable Broadcast Licenses be terminated? I say, YES!â€ Then, three minutes after that post, the president shared, â€œMERRY CHRISTMAS!!!â€

The episode of â€œThe Late Showâ€ that CBS aired on Dec. 23 was a rerun, featuring guests Sigourney Weaver and Mandy Patinkin. It originally aired on Dec. 8 â€” and that night, Colbert took several shots at Trump, including his takeover of the Kennedy Center and his move to seize hosting duties at the Kennedy Center Honors.

â€œThis yearâ€™s Kennedy Center Honors ceremony is the very first since Trump installed himself as chair of the Kennedy Centerâ€™s board,â€ Colbert said in his monologue, eliciting boos from the audience. In response, Colbert said, â€œYeah, I kind of agree. It seems like the commander-in-chief shouldnâ€™t have enough time to run a theater. â€˜Mr. President, Mr. President, Russia has just launched another round of missiles. But first, dress rehearsal for â€˜Oklahomaâ€™ is underway, and the blocking is uninspired,'â€ Colbert joked.

At another point, Colbert admitted, â€œI donâ€™t know how much effort Iâ€™m putting into the impression [of Trump] anymore. And I donâ€™t careâ€¦ Fire me!â€

Colbert also played some of Trumpâ€™s remarks in which â€œhe pre-complained about how people will judge his hostingâ€ of the Kennedy Center Honors, according to Colbert. Trump had claimed that as the ceremonyâ€™s host, â€œJimmy Kimmel was horribleâ€¦. If I canâ€™t beat out Jimmy Kimmel in terms of talent, then I donâ€™t think I should be president.â€ To which Colbert quipped: â€œYou canâ€™t and you shouldnâ€™t.â€

Then Colbert fact-checked Trump. â€œJust a quick brain check for Grandpa Puddinâ€™ Skull: I called [Kimmel] and Jimmy Kimmel has never hosted the Kennedy Center Honors,â€ eliciting a huge laugh from the audience. â€œBut hereâ€™s the thing: I did, the three years leading up to Trump becoming president.â€

In the monologue, Colbert also made fun of Trump for receiving the â€œfakeâ€ inaugural FIFA Peace Prize award â€œafter years of campaigning unsuccessfully for the Nobel Peace Prize.â€

â€œLater that same day, Trump also received the Hooters National Book Award,â€ Colbert joshed. â€œIt was the breast of times, it was the worst of boobs.â€ The CBS host said Trumpâ€™s FIFA Peace Prize is â€œlike for Christmas if you ask your mom for a Super Nintendo and she gets you something called â€˜Super Retendo.â€™ It comes with â€˜Super Marion Brothersâ€™ and â€˜Legend of Kelvin.'â€ Colbert said FIFA president Gianni Infantino â€œpulled on all the stops for Trumpâ€™s Big Boy Trophy Party,â€ adding that in a photo showing Trump picking up the medal Infantino awarded to him, the president â€œlooks like a goblin asking if itâ€™s OK to eat a third baby.â€

After CBS announced this summer that â€œThe Late Showâ€ would be ending in May 2026, Trump gloated that â€œI absolutely love that Colbert got fired.â€ A few days later on the show, Colbert fired back, telling the president, â€œGo fuck yourselfâ€ (with the f-word censored).

CBS, in announcing the cancellation of â€œThe Late Show,â€ insisted the move was â€œpurely a financial decisionâ€ that came after a years-long decline in the economics of late-night TV.

In its Dec. 23 broadcast of the Kennedy Center Honors, CBS did not refer to the place as the â€œTrump Kennedy Center,â€ largely because the ceremony was recorded before Trumpâ€™s name was screwed on to the building last week. CBS Newsâ€™ standards department instructed staffers last week to maintain the original Kennedy Center name in their coverage, the Washington Post reported. â€œIf the president or other administration officials use the new name in a soundbite that is their prerogative,â€ the news org said.
